title: 2017 OF69
text:
is a resonant <a href="trans-Neptunian%20object">trans-Neptunian object</a> from the <a href="Kuiper%20belt">Kuiper belt</a>, located in the outermost region of the <a href="Solar%20System">Solar System</a> in the Kuiper belt's <a href="plutino">plutino</a> population and measures approximately in diameter. It was first observed on 26 July 2017, by American astronomers <a href="David%20J.%20Tholen">David Tholen</a>, <a href="Scott%20S.%20Sheppard">Scott Sheppard</a>, and <a href="Chad%20Trujillo">Chad Trujillo</a> at <a href="Mauna%20Kea%20Observatories">Mauna Kea Observatories</a> in Hawaii, but not announced until 31 May 2018 due to observations made in April and May 2018 refining its orbit significantly.
Orbit and classification.
 is a large <a href="plutino">plutino</a>, a subgroup of the <a href="resonant%20trans-Neptunian%20object">resonant trans-Neptunian object</a>s located in the inner region of <a href="Kuiper%20belt">Kuiper belt</a>. Named after the group's largest member, <a href="Pluto">Pluto</a>, the plutinos are making <a href="Orbital%20resonance%23Plutino%20resonances">2 orbits for every 3 Neptune makes</a>.
It orbits the Sun at a distance of 31.4–47.8 <a href="Astronomical%20unit">AU</a> once every 249 years and 6 months (91,128 days; <a href="semi-major%20axis">semi-major axis</a> of 39.63 AU). Its orbit has an <a href="orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of 0.21 and an <a href="orbital%20inclination">inclination</a> of 14<a href="Degree%20%28angle%29">°</a> with respect to the <a href="ecliptic">ecliptic</a>. The body's <a href="observation%20arc">observation arc</a> begins with a <a href="precovery">precovery</a> by <a href="Pan-STARRS">Pan-STARRS</a> in June 2012.
Numbering and naming.
As of 2018, this <a href="minor%20planet">minor planet</a> has neither been <a href="Minor%20planet%20designation%23Syntax">numbered</a> nor <a href="List%20of%20named%20minor%20planets%20%28alphabetical%29">named</a> by the <a href="Minor%20Planet%20Center">Minor Planet Center</a>. The official discoverer(s) will be defined when the object is numbered. 
Physical characteristics.
Diameter and albedo.
According to the Johnston's archive, measures 533 kilometers in diameter assuming an <a href="astronomical%20albedo">albedo</a> of 0.09 for the body's surface. 
This makes a notably large body for how late it has been discovered, being the fifth largest plutino in the Solar System, after , <a href="90482%20Orcus">Orcus</a>, , and <a href="28978%26amp%3Bnbsp%3BIxion">Ixion</a>, and the largest discovered since Orcus in 2004. It is unknown exactly why no <a href="Astronomical%20surveys">surveys</a> had discovered it previously, as it is neither in a particularly <a href="Zone%20of%20Avoidance">dense region of the sky</a>, nor far enough south that most northern hemisphere-based surveys would ignore it, being only 5–6° south of the <a href="celestial%20equator">celestial equator</a>. It seems unlikely that any body as large as this one remains undetected in the plutino region.
Rotation period.
As of 2018, no rotational <a href="lightcurve">lightcurve</a> of has been obtained from photometric observations. The body's <a href="rotation%20period">rotation period</a>, <a href="Poles%20of%20astronomical%20bodies">pole</a> and shape remain unknown.
